title: How to Detect Wi-Fi Card Drivers on a PC: Windows, Mac, and Linux

steps.title: Open Device Manager.
steps.content: Open Device Manager. Press the Windows key to open your taskbar, type device manager , and click the Control Panel result.

steps.title: Click the arrow next to Network adapters.
steps.content: Click the arrow next to Network adapters . This expands the menu. Your network adapters will be listed here. If you have a wireless adapter, it should be obvious from the name of it (it might say Wireless or Wi-Fi). If it is not, you can do an internet search for the name of the device to learn whether it is wireless. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Press and hold the ⌥ Opt key and click the Apple menu.
steps.content: Press and hold the ⌥ Opt key and click the Apple menu. When you hold down the Option key and click the Apple menu, you'll see different options than you would otherwise.

steps.title: Click System Information.
steps.content: Click System Information . This opens a report that covers the hardware in your Mac. The shorter report may not list your Wi-Fi card, so make sure you have File > Show More Information selected.

steps.title: Look under "Network" to find a Wi-Fi card.
steps.content: Look under "Network" to find a Wi-Fi card. If your Mac desktop or MacBook has a wireless network card, it will be listed here. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open a Terminal window.
steps.content: Open a Terminal window. Press Ctrl + Alt + T to open a Terminal if you haven't already. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Type sudo lshw and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type sudo lshw and press ↵ Enter . When prompted, enter your account password to run the command. If your computer has a wireless card, you will see the information with "Wireless Card." [4] X Research source
